title-group.article-title: Rejection of nonharmonic disturbances in nonlinear systems via the internal model approach

article-meta.aff: School of Information Engineering, Nanchang Hangkong University, Nanchang, P. R. China

author-notes.corresp: Yuan Jiang, School of Information Engineering, Nanchang Hangkong University, Nanchang, 330063, P. R. China Email: jiangyuan9898@yahoo.com.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This paper proposes an asymptotic rejection algorithm for rejecting exotic disturbances in nonlinear systems. Disturbances produced by nonlinear exosystems are nonharmonic and periodic. The proposed algorithm extends the rejection of nonlinear disturbances for nonlinear dynamic systems from systems in the strict feedback form and output feedback form to general nonlinear systems. A new nonlinear internal model is proposed to deal with these disturbances. Furthermore, a state feedback controller is designed to ensure that the system’s state variables asymptotically converge to zero, and disturbances can be completely rejected. The proposed algorithm has various applications, such as active vibration control. The proposed algorithm is demonstrated to completely reject the nonharmonic periodic disturbances produced by a van der Pol oscillator.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Many engineering systems, such as turbo-machines, motors/generators, flexible structures, and communication circuits, are exposed to oscillatory input/disturbances of nonlinear disturbances, which are generated from nonlinear exosystems. A system’s output response to such oscillatory input signals is referred to as a nonharmoniously forced vibration (see e.g. Hu and Teel, 2007; Chen et al., 2008), which may have undesirable effects, such as noise, fatigue, precision and durability reduction, unreliability, and unscheduled shutdown. Reduction or cancellation of the unwanted vibration is important for the system’s stabilization, and has been a hotspot in various research fields for many years.

Globally asymptotic tracking and/or rejection of exotic signals is a goal for many control systems (Leyva-Ramos et al., 2005). Exotic signals can often be modeled as unknown deterministic signals with known signal-generating dynamics, which are referred to as the exosystem. The problem of asymptotic rejection of sinusoidal disturbance, which is one kind of common deterministic disturbance, has been widely studied (see e.g. Huang and Rugh, 1990; Isidori and Byrnes, 1990; Bodson and Douglas, 1997; Marino et al., 2003; Huang, 2004; Huang and Chen, 2004; Ding, 2007). A common assumption in studies of these problems is that the exosystem under consideration must be linear and neutrally stable. However, as the exosystem is nonlinear, few results are available. Recently, progress has been reported on output regulation with nonlinear exosystems (see, e.g. Byrnes and Isidori, 2004; Chen and Huang, 2005; Ding, 2006; Xi and Ding, 2007). A high-gain internal model is proposed to ensure semi-global output regulation with nonlinear exosystems (Byrnes and Isidori, 2004). The first framework has developed to study the robust output regulation problem with a nonlinear exosystem, and this paper is the only one to specifically address the existence of a steady-state generator and internal model when the exosystem is nonlinear (Chen and Huang, 2005). An output regulation algorithm has been proposed for a class of nonlinear output feedback systems with nonlinear exosystems (Ding, 2006). In addition, a new internal model was constructed based on a high-gain design and Hermite–Birkhoff interpolation (Ding, 2006). The approach has been extended to the application of the circle criterion (Xi and Ding, 2007). Similarly, an asymptotic rejection algorithm is proposed for rejection of nonharmonic disturbances in nonlinear systems (Chen et al., 2008), which uses the same internal model design approach (Xi and Ding, 2007) to deal with nonharmonic periodic disturbances produced by a van der Pol circuit.

In this paper, we aim to solve the disturbance rejection problem for a class of nonlinear systems, which is subject to some disturbances generated by nonlinear exosystems. The main contributions of the paper are the following: (i) the proposed rejection algorithm extends the rejection of nonlinear disturbances for nonlinear dynamic systems from systems in the strict feedback form and output feedback form to general nonlinear systems; (ii) a new nonlinear internal model for a class of nonlinear periodic disturbances; and (iii) a nonlinear regulator with servocompensation of the nonlinear periodic disturbances. The proposed method can be applied to active vibration control and nonharmonic distortion avoidance of nonlinear circuits. In addition, the proposed control design enlarges the class of nonlinear systems of which nonharmonic periodic disturbances can be asymptotically rejected.

The outline of this paper is as follows. Section 2 describes a class of nonlinear systems with a nonlinear exosystem as a disturbance source. Assumptions are also given. Section 3 is concerned with the nonlinear internal model design. In Section 4, the global robust stabilization analysis is given to determine the state feedback controller. An example is included in Section 5 to demonstrate the design procedure of the proposed method. Finally, the conclusion is drawn in Section 6.

sec.title: 2. Problem formulation
sec.p: Consider a single-input nonlinear system (1)x·=f(x)+g(x)(u-d), where x∈Rn is the state vector, u∈R is the control, and d∈R is a nonharmonic periodic disturbance generated from a nonlinear exosystem (2)w·=s(w),d=Γw, where w∈Rr,Γ∈R1×r and s(·) is a nonlinear function satisfying s(0)=0.

Assumption 1.
The flows of vector field s(w) are bounded and converge to periodic solutions. Remark 1.
On the basis of Assumption 1, the periodic solutions of the exosystems may include many functions, such as harmonic functions and limit cycles of nonlinear dynamic systems. Assumption 2.
There exists a function h(x):Rn→Rr such that (∂h(x)/∂x)g(x)=N, a nonzero constant vector inRr. Remark 2.
Assumption 2 is a condition for observability of the disturbances from the system state. If the vector field g(x) is a nonzero constant, there always exists a solution of h(x)=Nx for a nonzero N. For a general nonconstant vector field g(x), solutions can still be found (Isidori, 1995). Assumption 3.
Consider the disturbance-free system (3)x·=f(x)+g(x)u, where there exists a control law (4)u=α(x),

such that the closed-loop system (3) and (4) is asymptotically stable. Moreover, there exists a Lyapunov function V(x) such that (5)α1(x)≤V(x)≤α2(x), (6)∂V(x)∂x(f(x)+g(x)α(x))≤-α3(x), (7)|∂V(x)∂xg(x)|2≤α3(x), where αi(x), i=1,2,3 are class K∞ functions.

Remark 3.
According to the inverse Lyapunov Theorem (Khalil, 2002), Equations (5) and (6) are automatically satisfied if the closed-loop system is asymptotically stable. Equation (7) is always satisfied if the closed system is exponentially stable. However, there exist systems where the conditions in Assumption 3 are all satisfied, but the systems are not exponentially stable (Khalil, 2002). Assumption 4.
There exists a positive integer r and an odd locally Lipschitz function γ:Ω→R such that (8)drd(t)dtr-γ(d,d·,…,d(r-1))=0, where Ω∈Rr is a compact subset. In addition, there exists a positive number l, such that |γ(ρ1)-γ(ρ2)|≤l ‖ρ1-ρ2 ‖, where ρ1,ρ2∈Rr.

statement.title: Remark 4.
statement.p: Assumption 4 is motivated by Byrnes and Isidori (2004). We note that the disturbances satisfying Assumption 4 are more general.

sec.p: The problem considered here is defined as follows.

statement.title: Definition 1 (Asymptotic Disturbance Rejection with Global Stability):
statement.p: For any prescribed compact subset Dw⊂Rr, there is a state feedback controller u such that, for all w(0)∈Dw and any initial conditions of the plant and controller, the solution of the closed-loop system exists and is bounded for all t≥0, and that the system states converge to zero asymptotically.

sec.title: 3. Internal model design
sec.p: The rejection algorithm proposed in this paper adopts an indirect approach, that is, the disturbance is estimated first and then the estimated disturbance is used for control design. Thus, the crucial step for solving the disturbance rejection problem is to design a nonlinear internal model that can be used to estimate the disturbance. Firstly, we let (9)θ=col(d,d·,…,d(r-1)) Then, we have (10)θ·=Aθ+Bγ(θ), d=Ψθ, where A=[010···0001···0·····················000···1000···0]∈Rr×r,B=[00:01]∈Rr×1, ΨT=[10:00]∈R1×r.

We select any controllable pair (M,N) with M∈Rr×r,N∈Rr, where M is Hurwitzian and has disjoint spectra with A. Because the pair (Ψ, A) is observable, there exists a unique and nonsingular matrix T satisfying the Sylvester equation (11)TA-MT=NΨ.
Letting ϑ=Tθ, we have (12)ϑ·=TAT-1ϑ+TBγ(T-1ϑ), d=ΨT-1ϑ.

We design the nonlinear internal model as (13)η·=M(η-h(x))+TBγ(T-1(η-h(x)))+Nu+∂h(x)∂xf(x), where N∈Rr satisfies Assumption 2. Because M is Hurwitzian, so there exist positive definite matrices P and Q satisfying (14)PM+MTP=-Q.
We consider the mismatch between the states of (13) and (12), and define an auxiliary error as (15)η~=ϑ-η+h(x).
It follows that (16)~·η=ϑ·-η·+∂h(x)∂x(f(x)+g(x)(u-d(t))=TAT-1ϑ+TBγ(T-1ϑ)-M(η-h(x))-TBγ(T-1(η-h(x)))-Nu-∂h(x)∂xf(x)+∂h(x)∂x(f(x)+g(x)(u-ΨT-1ϑ))=Mη~+TBγ(T-1ϑ)-TBγ(T-1(η-h(x))).

sec.title: 4. Control design
sec.p:
Based on the internal model (13) and Assumption 3, the control input can be designed as (17)u=α(x)+ΨT-1(η-h(x)).
Theorem 1.
For the system (1), satisfying Assumptions 1–4, the control input (17) and the internal model (13) solve the asymptotic rejection problem with the nonharmonic periodic disturbance generated from the nonlinear exosystem (2). Proof:
Define a Lyapunov function candidate (18)W=V(x)+12η~TPη~, where P is the positive definite matrix satisfying the Lyapunov equation PM+MTP=-Q. Its derivative along the system dynamic (1) and the auxiliary error dynamic (16) is given by (19)W·=∂V(x)∂x(f(x)+g(x)(u-d))+12η~T(PM+MTP)η~ +η~TPTB(γ(T-1ϑ)-γ(T-1(ϑ-η~))) =∂V(x)∂x(f(x)+g(x)α(x)) +∂V(x)∂xg(x)ΨT-1(η-h(x)) -∂V(x)∂xg(x)ΨT-1(η~+η-h(x))-12η~TQη~ +η~TPTB(γ(T-1ϑ)-γ(T-1(ϑ-η~))) ≤∂V(x)∂x(f(x)+g(x)α(x)) -∂V(x)∂xg(x)ΨT-1η~-λmin(Q)2 ‖η~ ‖2 +η~TPTB(γ(T-1ϑ)-γ(T-1(ϑ-η~))) ≤-α3(x)+|∂V(x)∂xg(x)| ‖ΨT-1η~ ‖-λmin(Q)2 ‖η~ ‖2 +η~TPTB(γ(T-1ϑ)-γ(T-1(ϑ-η~))), where λmin(·) denotes the minimum eigenvalues of a matrix. Using Young’s inequality ab≤ɛa22+b22ɛ, we have (20)W·≤-12α3(x)-(λmin(Q)2-l ‖P ‖-12 |ΨT-1 |2)‖η~ ‖2, where l is the Lipschitz constant of the function γ.
Choose a real number (21)λmin(Q)≥2l ‖P ‖+ ‖ΨT-1 ‖2+1. Then (22)W·≤-12α3(x)-12 ‖η~ ‖2.

Note that W is positive definite and W· is negative semi-definite. Thus, η~ and x are bounded. According to (1) and (16), we can conclude that x· and ~·η are also bounded. Therefore we can conclude that all the variables are bounded. Furthermore, η~ and x are also square integrable over [0,∞) by (22). By Barbalat’s Lemma, we have limt→∞x(t)=0 and limt→∞η~=0. The proof is completed.

sec.title: 5. Illustrative example
sec.p: To illustrate the proposed approach, concentrating on the design of the nonlinear internal model, we consider a nonlinear system described by (23)x·1=2x2+x1 2+(u-d),x·2=-x2+11+x2 2(u-d), where the nonharmonic periodic disturbance d=w1 is the output of the following van der Pol oscillator: (24)w·1=w2,w·2=-w1+0.5(1-w1 2)w2.
Then, it is easy to show that d satisfies the following equation: (25)d··+d-0.5d·(1-d2)=0.
According to Khalil (2002: Lemma 3.2), γ is odd for locally Lipschitz functions over any compact subsets Ω⊂R2. Therefore, Assumption 4 is satisfied.
The disturbance-free system is stabilized by setting u=α(x) as (27)α(x)=-6x1+x2+x1x2-2x1 2+x2 3+13x1x2 3.
In fact, if we choose the Lyapunov function for the disturbance-free system as (28)V(x)=12(x2+13x2 3-x1)2+12x1 2, we have (29)∂V(x)∂x(f(x)+g(x)α(x))=-3(x2+13x2 3-x1)2-3x1 2,∂V(x)∂xg(x)=x1.
With reference to Assumption 3, we have (30)3+54 ‖x ‖2≤V(x)≤(2+(1+13 ‖x ‖2)) ‖x ‖2, (31)∂V(x)∂x(f(x)+g(x)α(x))≤- ‖x ‖2, (32)‖∂V(x)∂xg(x)‖2≤ ‖x ‖2

Therefore the system with the disturbance-free control design satisfies Assumption 3 with α1(x)=3+54 ‖x ‖2, α2(x)=(2+(1+13 ‖x ‖2)) ‖x ‖2, α3(x)= ‖x ‖2. With (33)h(x)=[4x1 -x2-13x2 3]T we have (34)N=∂h(x)∂xg(x)=[4 -1]T.
Hence, Assumption 2 is also satisfied. Note that Assumption 1 is automatically satisfied from the statement that disturbance is a nonharmonic periodic disturbance.

In addition, A=[0100], B=[01], Ψ=[10]. It is easily verified that the pair (Ψ, A) is observable. Let M=[-250-1], and then it is easily verified that (M, N) is a pair of controllable matrices with M being Hurwitz. Solving the Sylvester equation (11) then gives T=[-0.52.75-11].

Based on the proposed control method, the internal model and the control input are designed as follows: (35)η·=M(η-h(x))+TBγ(T-1(η-h(x))) +Nu+[8x2+4x1 2x2+x2 3], (36)u=α(x)+0.4444(η1-4x1)-1.2222(η2+x2+13x2 3).

In the simulation, let the initial condition be x(0)=[0, 0]T, η(0)=[0, 0]T, and w(0)=[1, -1]T. Figure 1 presents the phase portrait of the van der Pol oscillator. Figure 2 shows that the time responses of system states that converge to zero. As shown in Figure 3, the disturbance is well reproduced by the designed nonlinear internal model. The corresponding control input is given in Figure 4. Figure 1.
Phase portrait of the exosystem. Figure 2.
Time responses of states x1 and x2. Figure 3.
Disturbance d(t) and its estimate. Figure 4.
Input u.

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: The problem of rejection of nonharmonic periodic disturbances is solved for a class of nonlinear single-input systems that have the globally defined normal form. To reject disturbances generated by a nonlinear exosystem, a new nonlinear internal model is constructed. It is shown that the proposed controller ensures all signals in the closed-loop system are bounded and the system’s state variables asymptotically converge to zero. Simulation results illustrate the effectiveness of our algorithm. The proposed algorithm has various applications, such as active vibration control and nonharmonic distortion avoidance of nonlinear circuits. In a future study, a more delicate design algorithm of the internal model might be needed in this interesting topic.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was partially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No.60874009, Grant No. 61164015) and the Scientific Research Foundation for the Doctors of Nanchang Hangkong University (Grant No. EA201104184).
